questions.question_text: A workstation has just resolved a browser URL to the IP address of a server. Which protocol will the workstation now use to determine the destination MAC address to be placed into frames directed toward the sever?

discussion.content: ARP stands for address resolution protocol which works at L2 to forward mac address

questions.question_text: A network administrator has subnetted the 172.16.0.0 network using a subnet mask of 255.255.255.192. A duplicate IP address of 172.16.2.120 has accidentally been configured on a workstation in the network. The technician must assign this workstation a new IP address within that same subnetwork. Which address should be assigned to the workstation?

choices.D: Change the address of the serial0/1 interface of R1 to 192.1.1.4.
choices.B: Apply the clock rate 56000 configuration command to the serial0/1 interface of R1.
choices.C: Configure the serial0/1 interfaces on R1 and R2 with the no shutdown command.
choices.E: Change the subnet masks of both interfaces to 255.255.255.240.
choices.A: Ensure that the serial cable is correctly plugged in to the interfaces.

discussion.content:
This question is very misleading and A is the right answer.
The clockrate command is mandatory on back to back router connection using DTE/DCE cable. The clockrate have to be set on DCE side.
In this case, is not specified if router are connected back to back or through ISP DCE's, and is not possible check by the configuration. In some cases is possible that protocol stay down due to cable misconnection. 
However, the question is asked in an unclear way.
I agree with the answer and the explanation of paulosrsf. Thanks !

The correct answer is B. The two interfaces show UP for the layer 1. The problem is with layer 2 because of the message line protocol is down. If both interfaces are hardware up/protocol down, the problem is with encapsulation problems, like HDLC or PPP mismatch, or clock rate problems at the DCE.

Ignored: Number of received packets ignored by the interface because the interface hardware ran low on internal buffers. These buffers are different from the system buffers mentioned previously in the buffer description. Broadcast storms and bursts of noise can cause the ignored count to be increased.
No buffers: Number of received packets discarded because there was no buffer space in the main system. Compare with the ignored count. Broadcast storms on Ethernet networks and bursts of noise on serial lines are often responsible for no input buffer events.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. Which two of the output fields could help you determine if a broadcast storm has occurred? (Choose two.)
//IMG//
Which command can you enter to verify that a 128-bit address is live and responding?

discussion.content: ping IPv6 2000::1 is an example of command
The answer is C. On cisco router, you can just ping to any address, either ipv4, or ipv6. It just works. !!!!!

ping is only for ipv4 address and thos ipÂ´s have only 24 bits. 
if we want to test 128bits (the length of ipv6 address) we should use ping ipv6
